content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												Sleeping Dogs features Wei Shen, an undercover cop struggling to balance his Triad loyalty and police responsibilities on the streets of Hong Kong.The game features a well-crafted martial arts combat system, blending combos, counters, light and heavy attacks, and grabs/throws to create freeform fights that emphasize flow and diversity over efficiency. Environmental attacks and upgradeable special moves round out the variety.The real selling point is the map design - Hong Kong is lovingly rendered with beautiful levels of detail, from crowded market streets to curved highways overlooking endless rows of shipping docks. It's a delight to simply drive along the coastal highways and listen to the rippling shoreline or zip around the market districts. It's downright breathtaking, and stands head and shoulders above GTA's cities in terms of sheer visual interest.The story is solid, albeit a bit standard. Gunplay, driving, and some side activities like gambling or drug busts provide a solid variety of activities for the entire map. Music, sound and voice acting are top-notch.This is a a polished and cinematic take on the GTA sandbox formula, I thoroughly recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
A review for Sleeping Dogs : Definitive EditionIn this review, most of the review will review the gameplay of the game, as I seen that the meat of the game should also be in its gameplay. While some game will require great interfaces, games that are focused on open-world fighting/shooting should be focused on its gameplay.The first thing about this game, is that it has excellent gameplay, and quite varied with the well-established free-roaming games such as Grand Theft Auto series, Saints Row series, or Just Cause series. While four of them are great, the thing that makes Sleeping Dogs great is it have small amount of guns. It means that guns are hard to come by, most enemies don't have guns, and for the most part of the game you won't be using a gun.You won't be using your gun, but you are using your fist and your martial skill, this is what makes the game interesting. As with other fighting games, you can chain combo, do heavy strikes, block and counter, and other typical fighting moves. As you collect collectibles in the game, you will gain more advanced martial arts strikes, thus making you are more potent combatant. For most of the game you will face off with your enemy with Triad enemies with your fist, so fighting in the game have more color than its FPS aspect. In the fighting, you and your enemies will use believable melee weapons such as knife, tire iron, batons, meat cleaver, and not using melee weapons that are scarcely available in modern settings such as spears, katanas, or swords. This makes the fighting more realistic.The great aspect in the fighting is the environmental kills. These type of kills are brutal, that's for sure. You could stick someone's head in rotating fans, throw somebody to a flaming furnace, electrocute them with high voltage, throw them to the garbage bin, puncture their lungs using "sharp objects", drown them in water, and many more. In the shooting aspect, this game is also good. Not great, but good. The type of weapon did not vary very much, because then, as the story will tells you : "Guns are rare in Hong Kong." The game features a "shoot from cover" system and "blind fire" system, closely looks like GTA IV system, but there are some perks in shooting aspect, like you can enter slow mo mode if you leap from one place to other place. There is nothing new in shooting aspect, but it's good enough, in my opinion it's better than GTA IV system.In the gameplay, it's interesting also to note that your character is not Thor or something. The character will die quickly if shot at, making we more careful if we exchange fire with firearm-wielding enemies. While the character could take more damage in melee fighting, it's interesting to see that our character could not take much hit from firearms. It's quite real obviously, you could take three to four punches without dying, but two shots could kill you. This, and coupled with lack of firearms (and its ammunition) makes the police/law in the game very strong, because you could not bring your fist to a firefight.The ambience of Hong Kong is very greatly potrayed. I have been to Hong Kong for numerous times, and I would like to say that the spirit of Hong Kong is captured well. The signboards really reflects Hong Kong, as does how Hong Kong shop owners shout to the customers to ask them to purchase some DVDs, or how great their pork bun is. The street is also filled with Hong Kong cars, most notably the red taxi, the green small bus, the blue truck/construction worker transport, and many others. The street signs also are done in Chinese, so that the environment is greatly looking as the real Hong Kong. The only thing that I complains is there are lack of Chinese language use, because though Hong Kong people do understand English, in most times they are using Chinese, not English. While some "curses" in the game are obviously Chinese, I would like if the game respect Chinese language more.The activity of this game is somewhat bland. You have the regular racing (while you have to be #1, which is another thing I complain). You have fight clubs, where you will fight people. The only activity that interests me is the "drug raid" system, which are akin to GTA San Andreas hood takeover system. You fight some people, and you call something on TV, jobs done. There are lockboxes, shrines, and others as collectibles, but I don't see collecting collectibles as activities. For instance, there are no restaurants, no strip clubs, no bars, that you could interact. Story wise, this game have excellent story. I would not spoil it, but somewhat the ending is "expected". The twist of the game is "expected" too. If you have watched the movie about undercover agents you would know who will betray you. But, all in all, an excellent story.The "other" games that are provided in the Definitive Edition (the zombie, the police pack, etc.) are not going to be reviewed much, because they are not the meat of the game. While they are interesting, I would say that the DLCs are pretty bland. Purchase this game, and purchase that pork bun, because a man without a pork bun in their hand is not a real man.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is quite the thrill ride! It takes place in Hong Kong, and you take on the role of an undercover cop, Wei Shen. It is tasked to you to infiltrate the Triad gang known as the Sun On Yee (新安義), and become one of their own. Wei Shen starts his way into the gang by means of his childhood friend Jackie Ma, slowly gaining trust and respect along the way.The game is played in third-person, from behind the main character, though you have free camera movement to look from the front, sides, up, down, etc. There are various play styles along the way, from casual walking and running, to driving cars or motorcycles, to combat moments, parkour chases, driving gunfights, and so on...The visuals of the game are gorgeous, the city is bright and beautiful, especially when the lights all come on at night. When it rains, which usually is a pretty torrential downpour, is always visually beautiful, everything is wet and shiny. The surface of a simple puddle on the ground reflecting the world around it, it's absolutely stunning. When driving fast in a car or on a bike, the way the world streaks and blurs away in motion is great.There are clothes shops throughout the city that you can purchase different elements of clothing from shirts, vests, jackets, coats, pants, shorts, shoes, glasses, hats, chains, watches, bracelets, etc. There are also vehicle stores for purchasing cars and motorcycles throughout the city as well. Some clothing and vehicles are unlocked automatically through game progression, but most you will purchase as you make money on jobs and favours (and running over parking meters on the sides of the street with your car, haha).Many missions are presented to you throughout the game, some are through regular game progression, some you have to find, including small favours from shop owners, random people you meet on the street, fellow gang members, etc. These are optional, but I find that they are often very much worth doing, as you gain money and respect / influence.Gameplay is fluid, very smooth and natural, running, walking, driving... the parkour requires you to be smooth, you need to time your jumping over objects just right, or else you end up clumsily hopping over something and slowing down, trying to catch your bearings. The combat is sometimes difficult, and not so smooth. You will often have someone attacking you while you are dealing with one guy, and you need to counter their attack. Counters, grapples, and environmental kills are often fun, but have to be done just right (but those can often be quite brutal, yet satisfying).With the Definitive Edition of the game, you get all the DLC packs that were originally purchased separately from the main game, the key ones being Nightmare at North Point and Year of the Snake stories, which I would recommend doing after you have completed the main story. Year of the Snake pretty much takes you to right after the main game is finished, you're a beat cop investigating a cultist group planting bombs all over the city during the Chinese New Year. Nightmare at North Point takes you into only one area of the city, North Point (obviously) is only one of four areas you will see on your map. It is in this area that supernatural occurrences start taking place, as the undead start to rise by way of their leader Smiley Cat. But you gain some new supernatural abilities as well to deal with them.Overall, I had an awesome time playing this game. Put in about 70 hours at the time of this review. Main story and the DLCs, completed all missions and favours, and have 100% achievements. It was, as I said, quite a thrill ride, and I loved it. Highly recommended 9.5/10

												A great open world game with a lot to do, excellent cast and plot, fun fluid martial arts combat and some good action-movie styled gunplay/shootouts. The sidemissions in the game are generally fun, although the drug busts can get repetitive. The graphics are good, the model detail was good for the most part, although the detail on the civilians was pretty bad for the most part, as to be expected with an open world game.Overall, this game is a fun open-world interpretation of Hong-Kong. In my opinion it's worth more than the 30$ it's selling at right now. If I was to rate it, I'd give it an 8/10. Favorite Square-Enix game in my opinion.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
-Quick Review-Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is an Open World, with Third-Person Shooter and Martial Arts combat themes. There are many side tasks and side missions for you to run; races, fight clubs, gambling, police missions, and much more. -Detailed breakdown review-Story: You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop attempting to infiltrate a Hong Kong criminal organization known as the "Sun On Yee". Will Wei Shen keep his loyalties to the cops? will he become unstable from the stress? Will he be swayed to only work for the Sun On Yee and forsake his allegiances? You'll need to play to find out. (I'll tell you this much: I had no idea which direction we were going in this game.)


He stands alone, on the over pass with his smoking hot Motorcycle. 
A Screenshot of Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: (There's a lot to say about the Gameplay in Sleeping dogs, so I'm going to add more sub-topics. Hopefully that makes the information easier to read.)-CombatMartial ArtsThere are two types of combat in Sleeping Dogs; Martial Arts and eventually (when you get a gun) the shooting combat is played in third person. The Martial Arts section has different combinations of attacks; for example, click click click-and-hold, click click click click click-and-hold. However for most of the combo's you'll need to unlock by returning statues (hold that thought, we'll come back to that later).So you've got your clicky basic attacks, but wait! There's more! There is also grappling. By grappling you grab a hold of your enemy for a short time, you can proceed to beat your enemy like a drum with standard clicks... or you can embrace your inner monster and smash your new dance partner into an environmental object. You can do a special environmental kills with various objects which are outlined in red while grappling. (remember to make your choice fast, or else your dance partner will escape!)Arguably the most important features of the hand-to-hand combat is counter attacking, before most attacks the attacking NPC will suddenly have a red outline, at this time if you press the counter button ("E" on the default keyboard controls) Wei will execute various counter attacks, counters are extremely important, many tough enemies are nearly impossible to defeat without them.I would quickly like to make a few aesthetic mentions: the Martial Arts moves are spot on. I've been practicing TaeKwonDo for a few years, and watching those backspin kicks... oh! it's beautiful! Additionally the animation styles are very varied; so you don't keep seeing the same slow motion kills again and again, even after 30 hours spent in the game it's extremely satisfying to punch out someone, or if I get tired of that I could just put 'em in a dumpster.


Hello Face, I would like to introduce you to Mr.Table Saw 
A Screenshot of Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition
By: Atratzu




Third Person ShooterEventually Wei gets his hands on some weapons; there are plenty of them. The first few weapons will just be melee weapons, but eventually fire arms are introduced. At this point the game turns into a Third-Person Shooter. the significant feature of Sleeping Dogs where guns are concerned, is triggering slow motion after vaulting over objects while aiming.I have borderline-exploited this feature, I will spoiler tag my trick in case you want to figure it out on your own. While in slow motion I would score head shots on anyone in cross hairs distance. After slow motion stops I would just vault over another object to enter slow motion mode again. -DrivingThere's a lot of different types of vehicles you can drive; there are boats, motorcycles, cars, buses, motorized bikes, and many more. You can shoot while in most vehicle if you have a gun while driving. You can jump out of your vehicle and hijack other vehicles. You can smash into other vehicles by using a bashing or side swipe ability ("L-Shift" on the default keyboard controls) -Leveling/progressionThere's a lot to appreciate about the sense of progression in Sleeping Dogs! There are 3 different experience and levels: Police experience, Triad Experience, and Face Experience. Each level rewards a different skill or perk. Additionally there are many collectibles, the most important collectibles are various statues which can be returned to the Dojo in exchange for new combination hand-to-hand-techniques.-DLCUnfortunately (or maybe 'fortunately', depends on if you like my reviews. haha) I cannot write reviews for the individual DLC. But to quickly cover the DLC: It's good.There's a lot of DLC included with the Definite Edition, I think I've only gotten through a fourth of the DLC content. It's also worth noting that the Definitive edition was advertised as adding graphical improvements to the game. (It ran very well on my Windows 10 machine at 1080p, just a side note)Achievements: Oh boy... an analytical break down for the steam achievements would take far too long. At the time that I'm writing this review, I've successfully completed the story and maxed triad, police, and face experience (30 hours, many of those hours being distracted by civilian tag with cars).A good chunk of the achievements are allocated like most other games: story, extra's, missions, 100%, find all the things. I can't speak from first hand experience (yet), but a friend of mine has already earned 100% completion on the game.Price: Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is priced at $29.99 I just relaxed and enjoyed taking my time on beating the main story and I've already racked up 30 hours. with only 50% of the achievements it's safe to say I've got plenty of game time that'll increase after this review has been posted.For those of you unfamiliar with my value system: I like to get a hour out of a game for every dollar spent. So I'm saying this game was a great value, and will increase in value as I play it.Conclusion: All in all, if you like Martial Arts, Third Person shooters, Action, Open World action genre games, Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is for you. I was probably the target audience for this game, because I get really pumped while I play, in a way it helps inspire me for my next TaeKwonDo practice sessions.Special thanks to Angfucious for gifting me this game. You were 100% correct that I would love this game.P.S. The Umbrella Gang has it's eye on you. Umbrella gang! FOR UNCLE PO!


I'll probably use this for my review 
A Screenshot of Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition
By: Atratzu




------Edits and updates------Edit/Update May 03, 2016:corrected "Triads" with "Sun On Yee".Edit/Update, May 21, 2016:Added screenshots to help break up the text.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
Well... after finishing the story mode of the game in 2 days I can honestly say, this was an amazing journey.Introduction to the gameYou start the game as Wei Shen, a former police officer in San Francisco who's been transfered to a fictional hong kong which is split into four districts. Wei Shen has been assigned to destroy a Triad organization by the name of Sun On Yee.From there on out the game splits you into two characters - Wei Shen, police officer and Wei Shen, a member of the triad organization. Gameplay    → The Combat The combat system in this game is quite simple and easy to use, you fight with the click of your left mouse button and dodge incomming hits by pressing E at the right time. I really relish the fighting moments in the game where the character is faced off against 8 or more enemies at the same time, prooves quite a challenge at first but gets easier the more you do it. Another big thing in a lot of games are guns, not in this game though. You don't get a gun in your hand in the first 2 hours atleast into the game, you actually feel how powerful guns are in the game once you get them. You'll be spending most of the game fighting enemies with your fists or some other melee weapon rather then a pistol or an automatic.    → The VehiclesSimilarly to other games you can steal vehicles from a parking lot or the road by brutally janking the driver out, taking his place. Of course you don't have to steal vehicles, there is another to get a vehicle.There's a large variety of vehicles in the game for you to choose from. Once you obtain these vehicles in your garage you can choose 3-5 colors of your car and where you wish to recieve it from, there are multiple spots on the map from which you may take an infinite amount of these vehicles from. Some vehicles handle very nicely, others not so much. Occasionally you will run into a police situation from which you must escape and in this game it is quite easy, you just drive out of their detection zone and any ammount of police attention you had is just suddenly gone. Unfortunately there's no way of getting any air vehicles - Helicopters, planes etc. The sea vehicles are a bit of frustrating to control as they turn very slowly.    →The MinigamesSometimes you just want to take a break from the story mode but what do you do then? Do you go shoot people? Do you go explode cars? The answer is no. You go and sing karaoke ↓Me trying KaraokeIf karaoke isn't your thing you can also enjoy an exciting adrenaline rushing race in the streets of hong kong, or perhaps you feel like busting some crimes, you can!    → The collectiblesThroughout the map are placed many collectable items like statues, which you can give your old sensei in return for a new fighting technique. Then there are healing statue things which collecting will give you permanently more health, money can also be found in briefcases with sometimes a piece of clothing.     →The ExtrasYou can also purchase with ingame money clothing for Wei Shen which he will wear in any cutscene in the game, I think that's a very neat feature to the game aswell.The StoryThis game's story was really quite the journey, you can really feel the emotions of the characters in the game. Excitement, anger, grief, relief - all emotions that I've felt while playing this amazing masterpiece of a game, and if you really listen to the dialogue you will feel too. This is one of those games where once you start playing, you can't stop untill it's done.Final VertdictThis game has been a wonderful expirience for me and I suggest everyone to play it and enjoy it too. If you don't think you can run the definitve edition you should atleast buy the orginal. I'd rate this game a 10/10 for the pure depth of the game and story of it.

												Note: This review is about the changes in "Definitive Edition", not about the game itself. So what is the difference between the original version and definitive edition? Not much, it's just patched original Sleeping Dogs with full DLC and some improvements to the graphic that are either insignificant or unimportant. I can play the original version at max setting with solid fps, but I have to play this one on medium because the fps are too unstable (FYI, my spec is more or less the same as recommended), I also have a problem with ingame screen resolution, it causes me to have some kind of slightly visible letterbox appears at times, which is annoying because original version didn't have it. But as I said, the changes to graphic are insignificant. World density is the only improvement that worth mentioning, which makes the world more living by adding more cars, people on streets, NPC variations (less clones),... but this change can be achieved by a free patch, not a patch being sold. Also, still no Steam Cloud, wtf dev? Seriously? In short, Sleeping Dogs is an amazing game, but this Definitive Edition is a quick cash grab, patched games being sold at high price. Don't buy it if you already owned the original version, it's not worth it.For people with spec below recommended: Don't buy it because the spec given by the dev is inaccurate, you can play it on low smoothly, but it will look worse and less stable than the original version on medium. It seems the game doesn't use up all the CPU power, but depends mostly on GPU power, which means you need a strong GPU to play this game on high smoothly.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												This open world, third person action feels a lot like Saints Row with a more serious note. There's blood and scenarios are merciless.The game is mainly fought with fists, but guns are available on select missions. Some situations are crazy, specially the bike races - NPCs will ram the flag girl at the start. The rest of the way, they will go crazy on you.Car physics are not easy to control. Ramming (button) can also be used while going sideways, which could be exploited when racing or driving fast in general. If you think races are difficult, just race later after you have the prototype car - then races can get funny.Movement is also awkward (I am using a mouse and keyboard setup). Camera angles in any mode (car / bike / foot) is hard to control, and you can't look too far up (which I find weird and sometimes irritating). On foot, turning is not as precise or quick as in other games (or even compared to real life). This can be frustrating in fighting... until you realize that you can use a car or bike to win them. The game is probably programmed more towards using a gamepad.Soundtrack is good. I only started to get tired of them after more than 30 hours of playing.Graphics are good, but sometimes can't keep up when driving fast. It only required 50% at 750MHz from my GTX 770, so I think many gamers can play this game.Sound effects are amazing. It has perfect use of audio positioning and environmental sounds are there. Though, at times, motor boat and water splashing sounds were skipping (not produced) for a few seconds in intervals.The story is alright, and the story telling is fine. Events can sometimes get weird. You can't grab who you're chasing (even when you're already touching them) until you've reached the end where you'll fight a group or they simply give up; but at the same time, as part of the game rule, you can't be too far away from them (again, in a chase scenario).This game scored a 5/10 for me, but I'm labeling it as a Recommend for the story telling and overall good fun. The controls is the biggest let-down as I was forced to play with a hard to control character until I finish it. The game has a serious note, but remember that this is a game and better just take full advantage of what you can do to avoid character control, camera and other possible frustrations it could give you.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
Product received for free
												You'd be forgiven some trepidations about any game that's charted as ... unconventional a course to retail shelves as Sleeping Dogs. It first went into development at United Front Games as "Black Lotus," then transformed to a reboot of Activision's True Crime series. Then, as the mega-publisher let the game slide into the hands of Square-Enix, it lost the legacy branding and was re-redubbed Sleeping Dogs. The ship that emerges from those choppy waters is surprisingly seaworthy, but it's not without a few cracks in the hull. For some, Sleeping Dogs' leaks may be hard to ignore.Triad gangs took Hong Kong police officer Wei Shen's sister from him, and he's given up everything to take them apart. As Sleeping Dogs picks up his story, Shen's already deep undercover, embedded in a low-level position with the Sun On Yee (a thinly veiled nod to the Sun Yee On, a real-life Triad gang).Though the Hong Kong setting may be exotic, Shen's story will be familiar to anyone who's ever watched, read, or played a story of an undercover cop. As Shen gets closer to toppling the organization, he's also getting closer to its members, embracing their vicious, glamorous lifestyle until even the player may be left to wonder where, exactly, he stands.At first, the distinction between cop and criminal is easy to make. Shen has no firearms and so must rely on martial arts (and the occasional tire iron) to bring down members of rival gangs.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is a frenzied, artistic action game that, though it is marred by slight technical difficulties, still provides an enjoyable alternative to the standard action-sandbox.Sleeping Dogs' greatest strength comes from its presentation. The developers implemented the game's open-world replica of Hong Kong painstakingly with striking visuals and smartly interconnected layouts, which help the player see this beautifully-realized city from all angles. The characters' presentations are also done in an effective manner. The effort put into the story of the main character especially pays off, as gamers can easily identify with the upbringing and struggles that drive development of protagonist Wei Shen as he searches to define himself between connections with the Hong Kong Police and the gang Sun On Yee. Wei is joined by a cast of secondary characters that would generally fall into the category of "stereotypical", but fortunately most have some extraordinary developments or twists that keep them from becoming stale or predictable.Comparisons between Sleeping Dogs and the Grand Theft Auto series are commonplace. However, such claims made in an attempt to denigrate Sleeping Dogs is, at best, ignorant. Martial arts motifs play a significant role in the design of the gameplay here, composing the greatest difference between this and GTA. The player lacks the GTA-standard arsenal of weapons to carry around as combat is largely focused on hand-to-hand combat. Though some later levels heavily feature guns, players will largely find themseleves using combos and counters to dispatch foes. Other mechanics, ranging from a unique on-the-road hijack system to genre-standard slow-motion sequences further reinforce the kung-fu movie feel that the game is going for.Sleeping Dogs suffers from an array of technical malfunctions and limitations. The game in general works appropriately (no issues with rendering or framerate), though on rare occasion it crashed with no warning. Because the game generates cutscenes and scripted actions in the real game environment (i.e. instead of cutscenes being full video, the background of the scene is a continuation of what is going on with NPCs in the open world), unintended consequences often result. These consequences range from the hilarious (two characters showing indifference after being run over during a cutscene) to the catastrophic (being stuck behind an invisible wall after a scripted event, requiring reset). Getting stuck is moreso an issue with platforming in this game, as it attempts to emulate Assassin's Creed's parkour system, only to provide an unrefined version, leaving many instances of floating above objets or glitching around walls where one shouldn't be. Finally, the overreliance on the counter mechanism during combat makes it difficult to fight off groups of enemies as the game cannot handle many targets to counter at once. This proves especially troublesome during the beginning of the game, when Wei is too weak to take most attacks and must abuse the counter, leading to some unfair situations. This becomes less of an issue as he grows stronger in the game.In spite of this variety of issues the game faces, it was never enough to outweigh the positive experience that playing this game provided. It offers a lengthy primary campaign, bolstered by sidequests, completion goals and simple-yet-fun minigames. The Definitive Edition provides a significant amount of bonus missions and accessories to effectively bolster the length of the game after beating the main game. Additionally, it provides two scenarios seperate from the main game to play, which are both worthwhile in their own right. Though the final result of the game faced faulty implementation due to what the game was trying to accomplish, it still succeeds in providing a more visually-enthralling, narrative driven experience than is normal for action sandbox titles, and is a worthy game in any collection. Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition gets a B.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
 SLEEPING DOGS: DEFINITIVE EDITION REVIEW  Have you ever wanted to play Grand Theft Auto, but set in Hong Kong with tons of Chinese themes throughout the game. Well is Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition the game for you. The game has you playing Wei Shen an undercover cop who has to start getting in good with the Sun on Yee (Hong Kong Triad) and moving up in ranks and gaining their trust, but when Wei is getting taken off the case he insists on finishing the job he started, and that's what he intends to do.The game plays very well. The combat can be very smooth, maybe not to the extent of a Batman Arkham Game, but it's alright. Gun play in Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is a bit iffy and is only really acceptable when using a mouse, but I recommend the use of a controller for everything else. The cars control beautifully. Wei also feels very fluent on the ground when running and parkouring throughout Hong Kong.The game visually is pretty damn good and is a sight to behold. The original verson of Sleeping Dogs is no longer available on steam, but the definitive edition is basically the full package anyways. If you have a good enough pc to run it, it won't matter if the old version isn't available. GOOD GAME, COULD USE SOME ACTUAL SLEEPING DOGS NEXT TIME. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												I'll start this by saying that I've really enjoyed this game. A good mix between GTA and Saints Row. Story is cliche but engaging at the same time, although I was really hoping that there would be multiple endings at the end (it seemed like the story was leading to that). The game's story had the potential to top GTA's if they had put in multiple endings.GTA should do collectables like how Sleeping Dogs did it. The problem with GTA's collectables is that they had no value to it. Sleeping Dogs gave you upgrades for completing collectables. Thus, giving you the reason to go hunting them down.Combat system is one of the best for this genre, forcing you to use martial arts instead of going in guns blazing (not true for all missions, as the last few missions were gunfights). And note that I said 'for this genre'. Combat is definately not as good as the Batman series or Shadow of Mordor. And the chase scenes are amazing, as the freerunning system is simple but engaging at the same time.Problems only come in when you're trying to get all achevements and 100% the whole game. Bugs start to show, and I had to restart missions multiple times (sometimes even the whole game). Missions became tedious to do. At this point, the game got frustrating and I was playing it for the sake of completion. But this all started after the 25-30 hour mark.DLCs were mostly meh... 'Nightmare in North Point' was OK. You would probably enjoy 'Year of the Snake' if you really enjoyed the police missions in the main game.TL;DR Main story cliche but good. Brings new mechanics to the table for this genre. DLCs are meh. Game can become tedious and frustrating when trying to 100% it. Highly recommended.BTW, always remember, "A man who never eats pork buns is never a whole man."

number of helpful: 18 of 27 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												[Disclaimer]Sigh* I had already finished this game twice but steam didnt record that time nor achievement because I didn't have internet at that time 24/7 so none of my time or achievement register. The ones you see are just me checking to make sure the game is still alright before doing my review. Game Info Name: Sleeping DogsDeveloper: United Front GamesGenre: Beat Em Up, Kung Fu, Action, Stealth, RacingPersonal Verdict: Ever wanted to put a leg up someones face? Do so in HD. What is Sleeping Dogs:Definitive Edition Originally Sleeping Dogs without the Definitive Edition tack to it this version sees square enix adding and adjusting the entire DLC released in Sleeping Dog previous version into something well errr, better. Anyways to the game itself.Sleeping Dog is a visceral game of Kung-Fu, betrayal, triads and friendship as we follow one Wei Shen as he does his job in the brilliantly rendered world of Hong Kong, Wei must choose between his allegiance to the triads or to his police officers as he delivers justice. One Kung-Fu at a time. Story Playing the story of Sleeping Dogs [SD] reminds me of the old action Kung-Fu movie where the story moves at breakneck speed and emotional rollercoaster happens all the time. Which is to say the story kick♥♥♥♥♥ It delivers them in spades and is not afraid to hold back from doing all sorts of nasties that the player will no doubt witness and feel. Graphic Usually I do not like to talk much about graphics because what the heck am I suppose to write?! Exception of course are made. Sleeping Dogs treats the world of Hong Kong is pretty bland with repetitive civilian, normal texture etc etc but it really comes alive during the night and rain! Especially night and rain together in tandem! Skins exude a sheen, cars has powerful reflection upon them and everything is generally 10x better than it is during daytime. Not to say the standard graphics are bad but upping it up and witnessing the full glory of the engine in rain and night is a breathtaking experience. Sound United Front Games pulled no punches in making sure we get the most authenthic experience for our stay in Hong Kong. Random quips in Cantonese can be heard as you walk the streets, Character that do not speak english instead does full Cantonese dialogue. The crisp clear audio makes subtitle a secondary thing as oppose to be a mandatory on for most games and every effect down to the last mission complete evoke a strangely nostalgic chinese feel. Gameplay Ah Sleeping Dogs, I turn you on, kick a few citizen stuff them into the boot of their car then kill them right in front of the hospital with my KUNG-FU. What better way to start a monday.In an otherwise typical fare of open world game Sleeping Dog does the competition shame by focusing on one aspect many game have neglected: The melee system. While initially the melee system seems easy with 1 hko object scattered all over the enviroment and enemies come in weak and puny form they soon ramp it up especially towards midgame where you will be punching, kicking and hurling foes off rail while covered in blood. Essentially press counter when enemy glow red, punch them up till they die and then when the meter is full use face mode to recover health and make your enemy fear you. Along the way explore the world! Beat up people in side activities to uncover drug raids, beat people up again to obtain chests of money and clothing. Turn Wei into the most fashion savvy freak with the game large customization option. Engage in daring fights as you beat up people to get money and more face value! Or perhaps you're a picky one eh? Want a bit of dialogue and action in your beat em up? Look no further. Turn into a cop hunt down people as you become the scourge of the underworld, help your eccentric group of buddies as they get into random hijinks that often ends with beating people up. Or you know, just help around the citizen of Hong Kong, they could use a help from a friendly people-beating gangster. But alas the gunplay fall shorts, since most resources went into fighting people up the gun lacks recoil, feels plasticky and holds no weight. Cleverly the game wave them away from most mission by stating "HONG KONG DON'T ALLOW GUNS!" it works for me it should works for you. The car good to say however is awesome and a joy to ride, and since you can simply steal a car it doesnt matter if you're walking on foot, simply steal a car and be on your way. Or you can use the car valet. Eh. Fun feature includes the ability to steal cars within a car without going out. Amazing when you think about it since you don't have to dismount but can happily continue your ride in a shiny new car as the wreck of your old ones burns behind you.Completing mission earns you triad points by being brutal and police point for being civilised lawful cop. Leveling up gives you a choice of perk within the skill tree. An oddly choice of collectible, side missions and all that jazz ensures you won't be bored of the game anytime soon.  Conclusion How I wish i could experience it all over again, the powerful gunfight, desperate Kung-Fu action and emotional story. Why does more game can be this way? Alas a few minor issues does bog it down though. But does this makes it a bad game? It is an excellent game released suddenly to our world. Buy it already I am tired of typing this all out. Basically this game is awesome.Scoring Methology [Courtesy of Meat King]:-	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorVerdict: A++ RankCheck out the Original Network Groups. 												A suspense action-thriller, organized crime story, of a multidimensional Asian American undercover agent, whose loyalty is tested in extreme circumstances brought by a dark past he left behind.Hugely underrated, Sleeping Dogs is the surprise cult hit of 2012, and delivered an honorable tribute to masterpiece films, such as Infernal Affairs, and its Hollywood remake, The Departed.Sandbox gameplay set in a highly detailed cosmopolitan city, fully fleshed out with fresh style of slick eastern-esque aesthetics, well suited for the enigmatic Hong Kong Triad theme. Primary combat is raw hand-to-hand packed with myriad true-to-life martial techniques to employ; a feature that adds to its unique flavor when compared to GTA or Watch Dogs.Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition (2014) is more than worth the asked price point.  Experience this gem today!

Posted: January 5, 2015
												For those waiting for GTA V or a similar open world type game, Sleeping Dogs fills the gap suitably. The structure of the game is no surprise for any GTA player, or if you have played the previous True Crime games, with the only major difference here is that the game's combat is based on a Batman-style melee approach, which is suitably fun once you get the hang of it and identify the various moves. It does get a bit repetative towards the end of the main mission set, but that's common with most open world games; there's also a good deal of completionist gathering one can go after. However, elements like the story itself are somewhat lackluster - you can get an idea where the story is heading early on, and there's not much redeeming or vile about any of the characters. The Definition Edition includes two packs of DLC, both adding another 2-3 hr each of gameplay. The second one, Year of the Snake, feels like a good single movie in terms of plot (attempting to stop a cult bombing the city), while the first one has fun elements of movies like Big Trouble in Little China in it. The only issue that I have against the game is a lack of technical updates from the publisher, which many have commented on the forums. In my case, I had started the game, and during that time had to update a completely separate hardware driver for a camera device, among other things. This caused the game to be inoperable. Only until I was at a point that I had replaced the camera with a different one, did the game then work fine. As one of the few troubleshooting tips they have given has been to disconnect all USB devices which have worked for some but not all, this might create a technical problem for you.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Sleepings Dogs: Definitive Edition,Is the first game in its genre that's actually able to keep me interested. Game's like GTA and Saints Row, which do a good job on their own, don't come even close to what Sleeping Dogs offers me when it comes down to gameplay, handling, atmosphere, voice overs and hints of reality.The city of (virtual) Honk Kong is beautifully dirty and down to earth. The people all look very realistic and not like some comic book character. The cars look the way they should look: normal.There're many mini games throughout the main game and they all blend in perfectly and make sens in one way or another. It's nothing stupid, but fitting.Another good thing is that random violence is not rewarded, but rather punished. Especially when doing a mission.If you're looking for a game that's very similar to GTA or Saints Row, but want a somewhat more realistic setting, then get Sleeping Dogs. It provides action, drama, fun and visuals for content tourists; all on a very, very high level.The two DLC's that come with the definitive edition provide each 2-3 hours of extra gameplay and I've got to be honest that the "year of the Snake" DLC suprised me in a very positive way. That's because you're actually playing as a police officer. (Wearing the uniform and all) As which your main goal is to cover up some cultist scheme and to arrest people. (Opposite of killing)

content:
Posted: April 13
												If GTA is Metallica, Fallout is Megadeth, Saints Row is Anthrax, and The Witcher is Slayer...then Sleeping Dogs is Testament. A bit lesser known than the "Big 4", but right up there in quality; arguably better in some aspects. It's one of those games that although has Very Positive reviews is still somewhat underrated. It's got a cult following for sure.Gameplay-wise it's like GTA with Arkham style combat. It's unique in it's setting, story, and the fact that you play as an undercover cop. There is a fair amount of variety in the main missions, and the side missions / collectibles are awesome.If I had to name negatives I'd say the camera is a bit finicky at times. Also, the character models / lip syncing are not the games strongest points.Overall, a great game that should be played by anyone remotely interested in open world games. A solid 8/10.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I probably should have left this review on the original Sleeping Dogs game, but here we go anyways. Probably contains spoilers so consider yourself warned.\\ Story:The story is an amazingly tangled mess of triad fighting and personal choices. It is going to break you down inside and i was left a crying mess throughout the game. It should be said that i am very easily attached to, and affected by things. The wedding, where the oh so sad love song always plays before♥♥♥♥♥♥is going down, Uncle Po, and not to forget the most horrible death of them all (to me at least), Jackie.. The last had me bawling my eyes out because the story and character had sucked me in (and i kinda had a minor crush on Edison Chen). Anyhow, the story is solid, A+. \\ Gameplay and graphics:The improved graphics are stunning, and almost killed my computer because i was overly confident while choosing the ultra high settings. It was definitely worth the upgrade and it was even more immersive this time around than the first. I sat for eight hours the first day and ten hours the second to finish the game and i've never gotten so sucked into anything before. The vibrant colors and the city itself feels even more realistic now. I love the random encounters with people selling art and birds and whatnot too. And the food looks so amazingly good i just keep drooling every time i look at it.The only thing that annoyed me was towards the end of the game when the car valet kept saying he was busy and couldnt deliver to you, but apart from that i have nothing negative to say. Easily one of my favorite games and one of the best i've played so far.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												Spoiler free review.I like this game more than gta-series. Mainly because it has more serious story. Gta is fun, but i just personally prefer more serious approach. The story tells of an undercover cop, infiltrating and destroying a triad organization from within, but eventually, he becomes friends with them, and starts to notice, they might not be as bad as he thought. They're just humans, with relationship, and hardships in life that drove them to the criminal path.I really liked this aspect, it wasn't the basic "good guys are good guys, and bad guys are bad guys" type of setting. It was an interesting plot to follow.The city itself is lively, fun to explore, parkour aspect contributes to the joy of exploring, and gives new areas where to go. Sidequests are plenty, helping people, learning new martial art moves and hunting for collectibles. There's also police missions, in addition to the triad ones. But it seems they didn't really explore how they wuold collide, like really give a hint that you're on the danger of revealing yourself to the triad during the police missions.------------------The DLC-------------------------Definitive edition comes with all of them, of course. The first being integrate into the game, the zodiac tournament, is a fun little nod to Bruce Lee, and the one i found most enjoyable of the 3 biggest story dlc's. Nightmare in North Point is a horror themed, little and short dlc set only in North point, not much story. My second favorite of these ones.The last one, year of the snake continues from the main story, basically for the intro video. It was a big letdown, i mean a BIG. After the intro video, it's just mainly cop missions from the main game, put one after atnoher, and after few of them, it's done. That's it. There's some minor story dialoque in some "missions", when Wei is driving a car and talking on the phone for example. It seemed to me, that it was putten together hastily. When Zodiac tournament and Nightmare had more proper feel to them.

												Probably one of the greatest, if not THE greatest underrated game ever. I've replayed this 3 times on the PS3, 4 times on the PS4, and now going through my 2nd playthrough on PC. This game has a nice blend of badass kung-fu with equally badass gunfights. The story is great. You infiltrate, as an undercover officer of the law, into a ruthless Chinese Triad syndicate in Hong Kong, surrounded by people you knew in your childhood, and you must take down the entire Triad syndicate using legal and morally right methods, however, you also have a grudge against some of these guys, for what they did to your sister. The story, fighting, and side activites (which could've been better but are still fun to do) made me drawn to this game. It's great, and at $7.50, it's a steal.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												If you have played the original Sleeping Dogs released back In 2012 then you're probaly wondering why you should get the game again,well simply put the game Is amazing and Is more detailed and better looking then ever.The lighting In this game Is absolutely amazing and Is noticeable especially at night and when It Is raining,plus with the addition of Volumetric Fog you really feel like you're In Hong Kong.Also another Inprovement over the original release Is the Increase of NPC's roaming the street's of Hong Kong,more pedestrian's walking and the Increase of traffic throughout the city really bring's the game to life and give's you the feeling of the reality of everyday Hong Kong,the Night Market was one of my favourite place's In the game due to the fact that It Is absolutely crowded with NPC'S and you can constantly hear people yelling out to either yourself or other NPC'S trying to sell food or clothing,It make's you feel like you're In the everyday market's that are packed In Hong Kong.From the story's point of view I think It Is very well done and It Is really Interesting,I wasn't bored at any point during the game and the action got better and better as the story progressed,I would buy this game again just for the sake of the story alone because It Is very good.From the technical point of the game It Is extremely well optimized with a constant 60FPS! at 1080P however the extreme Anti Aliasing setting which use's SSAA Is extremely demanding and i would turn the setting down to high as I noticed no major difference in picture quality but did get better performance,also there was no game breaking bug's or freeze's.I would recommended this game to everybody,the story Is absolutely solid!,there Is plenty and I mean plenty of side mission's,collectibles and DLC's to be enthralled In.and also lot's of action packed fun exploring Hong Kong.So would I recommend people who bought the original Sleeping Dogs back In 2012 to buy the game again,absolutely!  If you never played Sleepings Dogs before,well then you must buy this game,It Is a one of a kind game and to both fan's and newcomer's of the game,It truly Is the Definitive Edition!

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												I've already reviewed the regular edition, so I've moved that review over with a few additional Definitive Edition-specific comments. The good: This is one of my favorite games, so I could probably fill a page with "the good." I find the story line extremely enjoyable. Being an undercover cop gives you a chance to cause mayhem while not feeling like a total dirtbag. The interactions between the player & NPCs are fun, and the voice acting is good. The setting and story really make you pull for a lot of different sides and think about life and family. The atmosphere is excellent. Hong Kong feels very vibrant and alive. The fighting system is one of my favorites. There are few guns available in this game; instead, the game mostly relies on martial arts. There's a gym where you can practice your moves before you take on street thugs and rival triads. The bad: The driving is kind of awful. I've tried it with a controller and liked it slightly better, but it still wasn't great. However, once you get used to it, it's playable, if a little frustrating. I thought the main campaign was rather short. It's an open world game with lots of side quests, but the way each of the main quests comes up sort of gives you an urgency that can push you through the game at a faster pace. I raced through a lot of the main quest and suddenly went, oh, that's the end? Definitive Edition comments: Almost all of the DLCs from the original edition were bundled into the Definitive Edition. They removed the (what I considered to be) game-breaking DLCs that gave you tons of money and XP right at the beginning, so the game progresses in a much more natural fashion now. All the outfits previously added by the DLCs are available for purchase at the Night Market; Wheels of Fury missions are now spread out so that you don't gain a super OP car immediately. The textures, graphics, and higher population density of the Definitive Edition may cause performance issues on some systems. I have an Nvidia graphics card and had to play with my settings to get the game to run on that card rather than my integrated graphics. General info: The open world provides ample opportunity for exploration and side quests. The story is great and the world is very atmospheric (Hong Kong makes a nice change from the generic cities a lot of games are set in). The art style is fairly good (better with the HD textures). Overall: I would definitely recommend this game! If you haven't played it yet, you need to!System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Sleeping Dogs takes you on a blood-spattered journey through the violent Hong Kong underworld as undercover cop Wei Shen, a man torn between two worlds and not wholly of either one. The game is a sandbox crime sim and is closer to Grand Theft Auto then to Saints Row in terms of gameplay, but is generally more enjoyable to play then the former. It does however lack any kind of multiplayer, which I am sure would be very offputting for some. While it places a much lower emphasis on shooting then most games in the genre, it flavors its gunfights with bullet time- but most of the time, Wei engages his foes with a brutal combination of strikes, counters and throws, coupled with some very painful-looking environmental finishers (table saws, spikes, furnaces, fan blades- the list goes on) You unlock additional melee techniques along the way and while the fights may eventually get stale and lack the tactical depth of say, the Batman: Arkham games, they remain a cut above the drunken flailing that passes for melee in GTA V. Unlike the purely aesthetic clothing options in GTA V, clothing in Sleeping Dogs can provide bonuses when worn as a set.  Driving is manageable, though most the cars do not handle very well and you will find yourself grinding a lot of hard surfaces at speed. However, you have the ability to jolt your car left, right or forwards to ram other cars, which is both useful and entertaining. Bullet time also kicks in when aiming a gun from a car, making engaging pursuers infinitely easier. As per standard for the genre, there are a multitude of collectables scattered about the map. While the lockboxes reward only some money and occasionally clothes and the security camera hacks offer no reward at all, the shrines confer a maximum health upgrade for every five shrines found and are absolutely vital, as finding them all doubles Wei's starting health. Luckily, you unlock the ability to see the shrines on your map early on, and like GTA V, the entire city is available to explore at the start, barring only a few story mission-only areas.  This "definitive" edition of the game includes almost all of the DLCs- fair enough, considering the vanilla edition is no longer available (Wow Squarenix, really?) These include a number of extra outfits, vehicles and missions that if used/done during the course of a playthrough will make the core content much easier, especially the police tactical gear that cuts all damage you take in half. There are a pair of mini-story addons, one dealing with a prototype, gatling-equipped supercar and the other a martial arts tournament ripped straight out of Enter the Dragon, which offers up some of the most difficult melee fights in the game. Money is also no object beyond the first few hours of the story, beginning with the fact that you can run over parking meters to get it! There are also a pair of full story addons: Nightmare on North Point is your standard horror-flavored DLC that has you fighting Jiang Shi vampires, Yaoguai demons and the ghosts of enemies fought in the main campaign. The second, Year of the Snake, sees Wei back on the force and combating a bomb-crazy doomsday cult on Chinese New Year's. While Nightmare has new enemies and Snake has some good gunfights, both DLCs are somewhat repetitive and are not up to the same quality as the core campaign. They are, however, short enough that they do not overstay their welcome. Though I played these addons after completing the story, you may wish to complete Year of the Snake earlier on as it adds a tear-gas grenade launcher to your main playthrough. Overall, I enjoyed Sleeping Dogs and found it more then worth its lowered price. If you enjoy sandbox crime games, Sleeping Dogs is certainly worth your time.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												One of the most highly underrated open-world action single player game to come out.  The story is based on a lot of similarties to most HK typical traid vs traid vs police.  However the story is very well done and well paced.  The melee combat is fun and fluid once you get the hang of it and does not take long.  The gunplay is very familair to max payne, which is a good thing.  The graphics still holds up really well with this definitive edition even though this game is almost 5 years old.  The city looks amazing at night with all the lights and reflections. The city really feels alive with lots of npcs, cars,stores, attractions, etc.  Also if you do play in very high resolution like 2k or 4K like myself, there is a UI scale option which is perfect.The voice acting are excellent.  Some very big name in the asian film industry gave the voices to the game and really shines during cutscenes.  The soundtrack also very good.  With mix of chinese traditional music, to hip-hop, instrumentals, dance, and pop songs.   I often took longer route to my destination just to hear more of the music, which says a lot.  Car controls well and is definately way better than most open world and even more of the recent releases.  This game really didn't get a lot of attention when it first released but it should not be missed.  One of the best sleeper hit to come out in the past 5 years.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs was originally released on August 13, 2012 for Xbox 360, PS3, and PC. It was recently released on Xbox One and PS4 as well. It was developed by United Front Games and published by Square Enix. It received a 9 out of 10 on Steam, 4 out of 5 on Metacritic and an 8.5 out of 10 on IGN.While most people consider Sleeping Dogs a GTA knock off set in Hong Kong, I would argue that perception is false. While the initial concept is the same, an open world crime game, the basic mechanics of Sleeping Dogs sets it apart. These mechanics include cop/triad alliances, a focus on melee combat, and a Max Payne esque bullet time when sliding over objects during gun play.Because of the great implementation of the aforementioned mechanics, the smaller size of the open world compared to similar releases such as GTA and Watch_Dogs, still provides a fantastic experience.The story in follows an ex San Francisco cop that has been thrown back into the world of the Triads in modern day Hong Kong. While the story may seem cliche at first, if you give it some time you will find a rewarding plot line to follow.The Definitive Edition includes six downloadable content packages for your consumption, and with the current holiday sale on Steam, is well worth the additional cost.

												~ One of the best games that I have ever played! ~It's a gorgeous 3rd person shooter! It includes a ton of DLC, which are rebalanced and properly integrated into the game's story, unlike the standard edition of Sleeping Dogs. The DLC do not give you an unfair advantage anymore. Also, some DLC are unlocked as you progress through the main story and there are two more DLC that can be accessed from the Main Menu, which are separated from the main game.It's a great PC port, featuring DX11 support and an integrated high-res texture pack.  For me, it was a real pleasure driving around this fictional Hong Kong, killing bad guys and enjoying the beautiful storyline :)

content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												While I like the graphical improvements and other tweaks, I must say I'm somewhat disappointed with the lack of bug fixes.  There's a few times where you can fail a mission randomly due to bad AI (ie: if you have an ally driving for you and they flip the car) or just some inexplicable auto-fails.  Nonetheless, the concept of the game is very appealing and is mostly well done.  It doesn't have the same polish as GTA in some ways but the martial arts combat system and parkour is way more advanced than what GTA has.  One terrible thing in this game is that you can't seem to hail a cab without car jacking half the time.  Nobody thought of using  another button for the car jacking?  Bugs and minor headaches aside, it's definitely a buy if you haven't played the original version and love games like GTA and Saints Row.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												I have played the original Sleeping Dogs quite a bit since 2013 and it has grown to be one of my favorite games of all time. So much so that I figured it would be a crime if I did not buy the new Definitive Edition. After play for an hour, I have to say that I am impressed by the Definitive Edition. Right off the bat, the menu is ultra-sharp, even in 1920x1080p. Even the menu sounds and menu music quality have been improved! The introduction is better than ever; I had an absolute BLAST with the new destruction mechanics in the beginning chase and fights. I threw an enemy at a cabinet and the drawers of the cabinet actually came out and papers flew out. Then, I slammed a metal gate in the market on top of an enemy and it actually bent in the middle. This kind of stuff never happened before... I love it! The electronic street signs have been improved (all the textures too) to make Hong Kong look better than ever. The rain effects look phenomenal, and I have realized that the map, loading dragon, in-game floating HUD icons, etc. are almost 4k sharp. Many other elements of the game have been improved as wellIf you already have Sleeping Dogs and love it to death (and have extra money), get it. If you have not played it at all, get it. If you already have the Definitive Edition, play it! :)

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												It's a really good GTA clone that recreates the tone of classic Cantonese action flicks. What makes it interesting is that it incorporates an Arkham-style martial arts fight system with the guns and cars.Note that this "definitive" edition comes with all of the DLC they ever produced, and a lot of it is way off tone from the base game. The costume/moveset addons let you conduct undercover police operations dressed as Wukong the monkey king, or cosplaying as Jensen from Deus Ex. There's a series of optional missions in which you build a ridiculous Bond car with an EMP generator and dual minigun turrets. The story DLCs are also pretty zany. There's an optional mission where you get sucked into a '70s kung fu grindhouse movie, and an expansion that's a horror comedy about an invasion of hopping vampires. So if you're big on immersion and just want to stick to the Infernal Affairs-style cop movie storyline you'll probably want to avoid doing any of the DLC.If you're looking for an open world game without any of GTA's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, this is definitely worth buying during a sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												I read that a lot of people compare it to GTA. Since I don't play GTA, this review will try to cover and talk about aspects that maybe GTA has too. Therefore, sorry if some of the points may look, from your point of view, like something to be expected from a 2014 game and shouldn't be seen as selling points.The plot is truly interesting, and although is widely known that you take the role of an undercover cop, things are not as plain as it may seem. You're not an average undercover cop, you're a person suited to fill that role, with a particular psychological profile. You'll infiltrate in a main branch of the Triad, in Hong Kong, and things won't go as smooth as you'd like. That profile won't help and you'll get caught in something a bit more deep, a bit more scary, a bit more of your own.It won't be about choosing sides, it will be more about merging in both, without leaving any trace, nor any part of you.It will be more about swimming inside a stream, while trying not to follow its flow.Gameplay - Wise, I didn't feel disappointed at all. The environment is gorgeus, accurate, colourful yet gray. Turns, hills, alleys, signs.Driving is fun but steering is a must, and makes things more exciting. Shame there aren't many car models. You can't steal a car and make it yours by driving it into your parking lot, but you'll own many cars, obtained by buying them or by doing main missions and / or side missions. Same applies for motorcycles.While cars can't be customized, noone says that you can't steal them and drive them through all Hong Kong, shooting at other cars' tires or directly at their front window. Aim well for a clean headshot, will you? Or if you feel like you need a new car, keep putting the pedal to the metal, jump from your seat to the roof of your new love interest or hit them until they'll stop driving.And there will be lot of pursuits. Relentless pursuits. Be it in North Point or in the highway, drive wherever you want, just get rid of the pursuers. This is one of the things I liked most from the game, as it's one of the few cases where you'll hold a firearm and you'll see cars exploding.Because what has been seen by many as a flaw, my eyes and my racing heart tells me otherwise.Firearms are rare, very rare so that you won't feel overpowered and start a killing spree. You'll treasure them and hide them. You won't waste bullets and you'll scavenge a lot. And you'll enjoy the moment when you'll use your gun to set a car on fire, or while taking cover behind a counter, against a volley of bullets.Gunfires will make you remind that you're made of flesh, so don't try to run against your enemies. Take cover and plan the right time to shoot.This scarce source of guns makes hand-to-hand combat the way to clean the path ahead of you. Keep countering, break their arms, thair legs, their teeth. Use everything at your disposal: a fan, a swordfish, a boiler, a railing, or take them hostages and use their bodies as shields, or put them inside the boot; they may change their minds.There's still more, but I don't think I should spoil everything.Secondary missions are interesting, they add layers to an already thick background, encouraging you to live this game more deeply, on both sides of the same coin.They will encourage you to explore to the fullest the map, uncovering favors, races, secrets and so on.Buy it, because I didn't tell you everything, and because it deserves more sunlight than shades.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												A very good game, it's very addictive and enjoyable to play. I recommend if you enjoy open world games like GTA and Saints Row, it's simular to that, but unlike those games that are US based, Sleeping Dogs is refreshingly oriental, based in Hong Kong. With good martial arts combat.This is a open world game, with martial arts, crime, street racing, gambling,  with main missions, various side quests and hunting for collectibles. You don't get to use guns till later on.The main character you play as is Wei Shen a undercover cop who infiltrates and works with the triads to try and take them down, so you get to partake in criminal activities without really being a criminal and find yourself getting deeper into the criminal world. The story is very good and I could not help but feel sad when certain things happened even though they are criminals.The driving in the game at first feels terrible, until you get cars with better handling.Only thing I really hated was the phone tracing mini game, at first I did not get what I had to do, you have a limited time to trace the person and I kept failing it and having to start it all over again. And even when I did get it, it usually takes me a couple of tries as it does not give you enough time.The only thing  that was a bit weird was that enemies can put their fists up to block, but Wei has no block ability, he can only use counter on most attacks used on him.I didn't experience any major glitches or problems with this game.I had minor glitches such as a few times when entering a car Wei would get flung away from the car, causing a mission to fail as it said I left the area :pWith the DLC's they are short and I enjoyed Nightmare in North Point, it had an overall creepy feel to it.  Year of the Snake even shorter and not as fun. Zodiac Tournament was alright, a bit annoying.It's good that the DLC is included in the definitive addition as to me they don't seem worth paying extra for as they are very short and don't have much content and are more like tacked on side missions. And the bad thing about the Dlc's is they are seperate from the main game and you can't use clothing and cars that you have previously bought so you end up stuck with only boring police vehicles in your garage when you play the year of the snake and no awesome DZS-90 wheels of fury car.Short DLC aside This is a must play game, a game is really good to me when I can't stand the thought that it's going to end. I highly recommend this game. 8/10 a must play.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Sleepy Dogs is one of my all time favorite open world games. I played this game for the first time last year and promised myself that I would eventually buy all of the DLC and replay the game eventually.  When the Definitive edition came out, I knew I had to get it immediately.  The DE sprinkles the newly unlocked DLC throughout the story so you are not immediately over powered at the start with crazy guns/cars/money.  That was a very good thing and added much to the overall gameplay.  The graphic upgrade was a nice touch as well.  In all, if you are thinking about buying Sleeping Dogs the DE is definitely the one to get.2015 Edit: After playing GTA 5, I can safely say that I enjoyed my time with this game more than Grand Theft Auto. I wish that Sleepy Dogs could have a touch more of the amazing world building that GTA has. But that's it. I S ranked this game and would STILL be willing to take another spin in the world of Sleepy Dogs.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Graphic is improved obviously. But the control is not as good as the original Sleeping Dogs I played 1 year ago. First is the control, its  not as responsive as before, plus the camera is a bit frustrating, its hard to adjust the camera when I am driving. And button mapping is different than the original Sleepiong Dogs, I like the original button mapping, E for hijack/talk/interact, right click for counter, and space for running/ramming vehicle/climbing. In this definitive edition, counter/hijack/ interact is the same buttong. Running and climbing using left shift, took a while to adjust the control. Not serious problem, but it could be better. I like the fighting mechanism in this game, tho the unresponsive control sometimes makes me go into rage, I can still manage my mental state good enoughThe game's content is great, worth the price, but why does it have to be vampires? And Wei only has his fist to fight the vampires and sword (sometimes) only to kill demon, this is Wei too much man. 5 vampires jumped at me, I counter, the result of unresponsive control, got bitten a lot, and when u are faced with 5 vampires and the jiang shi, a little bit chaos. Last is the clothing, why does 1 outfit has to be worn as 1, I can wear them separately. Dont like it. And the super fast police car is tied to the side mission only. Cmon, it would be fun to be able to ride this epic fast car in a free roam and mess with the police when I'm in it. And when it comes to driving in a race with super fast car, get ready to be♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Remember the camera? Yeah, the camera is the main enemy here. I am going to buy a controller for this game, I hope it would improve my in game experience.Conclusion, recommended, but only if you didnt buy the original one.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												2013 - Rushed through campaign and really enjoyed the gangsta/cop story, 24 achievements.2016 - Bought the definitive edition on sale and played all of the content. 59 achievements and didn't get tired of the game until I had to get 30 gold awards + 5 for the Nightmare In Northpoint DLC which was actually pretty fun for about an episode or 2's worth of time.So the reason I went back to this game and 100 percented it.I love this game. It's as simple as that honestly. Sleeping Dogs has a great Oriental Cop/Gangster story, its like Super Cop meets Enter the Dragon meets some badass movie with Triad gangsters in it. You are Wei Shen an undercover cop bent on infiltrating the Triad and bringing down the worst of them for justice and possibly revenge. Sure the gameplay is a GTA clone but honestly why would you care? The GTA series were great games and Sleeping Dogs is the Oriental cousin GTA never really had. The story has a good familiar feel to it and is a little predictable at some points but this shouldnt discourage you if you are a fan of the genre. The extra content from the DLC's are fun concepts especially Nightmare In Northpoint, I wasn't a fan of Year of the Snake but I feel like outside of story content the Wheels of Fury DLC made up for what YoTS lacked and that is the DZS-90 (please drive irresponsibly).Combat is very fun throughout the game but can get very repetitious as per usual with this genre. also I loved the missions, most of them are quick and easy and somewhat challenging. Alot of costumes you get from the extra content directly affect your combat strength/XP gains.Dating in the game is a means to an end and the only regretful aspect.The achievement system is actually super easy. They are a little grindy but easily doable.Thanks for reading this short review I give this game 8/10 enjoy!

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Before I start my review of this product, I would like to mention that this is one of my first gaming experiences on the PC and this game has won me over. At the time of reviewing this, I have put in 90 or so minutes into the game so you could consider this a first impressions review. OverviewSleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is a revamp of Sleeping Dogs with improved graphics. Wei Shen finds himself at ends when he gets in too deep with the gangs of Hong Kong as you work undercover for the police to infiltrate the Sun On Yee gang. Rating/Topic+ GraphicsLet's start at the graphics, which is a selling point for the definitive edition. The game looks amazing and the city of Hong Kong has a feeling of immersion like nothing I have played before. The graphics are great and they do live up to the marketing of the definitive edition. Overall, this department is solid. - ControlsMy second topic is the controls for keyboard and mouse. I really am not a fan of them, but I don't like KB&M for most third person games either. I guess they are okay if you are good with a keyboard and mouse in third person games, but I found it to be a much better experience on the Xbox One controller. The game recognized the controller immediately and I was very satisfied without needing to change any of the default controls. The KB&M controls aren't as stellar as the graphics, but they are decent. I recommend a controller to get the best experience for this game.+ Storyline The storyline is a modern masterpiece. I have played only 90 minutes, yet I can say that the story has excellent pacing and makes you think about your actions. I went in playing the game like GTA, but every car you steal and every rival thug you beat up alters your opinion and immerses you into the game like nothing I have experienced. I can't emphasize how enjoyable it is to play this game. After a session of gaming, I sit back as if I am Wei Sheng and contemplate my actions like the game is real life. Overall, the story is amazing and is a huge selling point of this game.+ CombatThe combat is simple enough for me as someone who does not play fighting games, I found the combat sequences to be at a good middle ground for difficulty. The camera shakes as you slam someone against the wall and you can feel each hit you put on your opponent. The AI is great and thugs will be less likely to attack you when you push one of their face's into a fan or smash someone against a telephone booth. This game is great at immersing you into every aspect of the game. In all, the combat is just as solid as the graphics and storyline. Other Notes+ The soundtrack fits the theme very well+ Traffic and NPC's are very realistic, a must for a game set in one of the biggest cities in the world- Driving feels a bit clunky+/- Little to no gun combat, which could be a plus or minus depending on how you feel+ Definitive Edition includes all DLC's+/- Okay optimization, got a stable 60 FPS on high @ 1920x1080 on an OEM GTX 760, which gets 4-5 frames per second lower than a normal 760. Quick pro tip here, running this game on the Extreme preset enabled will turn on high SSAA & FXAA, which will eat up your FPS without providing much visual difference. Best to use a custom preset and switch to high FXAA and medium SSAA. SummarySleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition lives up to it's claim of improved graphics and delivers a very enjoyable gaming experience, but the keyboard and mouse experience is not the best. I recommend a controller, and be weary that the Extreme graphic preset enables high super sampling anti-aliasing which will eat up FPS, I recommend using a custom setup and use medium SSAA and high FXAA if you have a mid-tier graphics card such as the 270X or 760. I would happily recommend this to anyone who has enjoyed games such as GTA, Assassin's Creed, Watch Dogs or any of the Batman games. It isn't the most recent title, but the definitive edition includes all the DLC's and the updated graphics are on par with 2014 releases. My overall rating for this game is a very sold 9/10.
